item.description:
This looked interesting in the previews and has received strong reviews.  From the Cinestudio website:

July 14, 1789: the storming of the Bastille sparked a revolution that would irrevocably change the world. Farewell My Queen brilliantly re-lives that moment in time through the emotional lives of four women living at Versailles; Sidonie (Léa Seydoux) a lowly attendant whose job it is to read to the Queen, a slyly suspicious lady-in-waiting (Noémie Lvovsky), the Queen’s charming “special favorite” (Virginie Ledoyen), and the bored and flirtatious Marie Antoinette herself (Diane Kruger).

Director Benoît Jacquot’s (Sade, A Single Girl) film is a masterpiece of contrasts that still resonate today, between the lives of the rich and the poor, and between the unchallenged status quo and the unknowable future. “History tells us how this story ends, but history is rarely as passionate as this!” Kenneth Turan, Los Angeles Times.

 

(France, 2012) Directed by Benoît Jacquot.

Screenplay by Gilles Taurand and Benoît Jacquot, based on the novel by Chantal Thomas.

Cast: Léa Seydoux, Diane Kruger, Virginie Ledoyen, Xavier Beauvois, Noémie Lvovsky.

97 min.
